facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 50 of 1957 in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTIONCriminal Appeal No. 50 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated January 27, 1956 of Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 27, 1956, of the Rajasthan High Court at Jodhpur in Criminal Appeal No. 119 of 1954 arising out of the judgment

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court Criminal Appeal No. 119 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: in Criminal Appeal No. 119 of 1954 arising out of the judgment and order dated March 23, 1954, of the Court of the Sessions Judge at Ganganagar in Original Criminal Case No. 74 of 1953.

facts.text: Sessions Judge at Ganganagar judgment dated March 23, 1954 in Original Criminal Case No. 74 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated March 23, 1954, of the Court of the Sessions Judge at Ganganagar in Original Criminal Case No. 74 of 1953. Mohan Behari Lal, for the appellant.

facts.text: Bhagwandas, Netram and Mt. Rameshwari tried by Sessions Judge of Ganganagar for offence under s. 302 IPC and acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR J.-Bhagwandas and Netram are two brothers who along with Mt. Rameshwari, a daughter of the former, were tried by the Sessions Judge of Ganganagar for an offence under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code but were acquitted.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court reversed acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram, convicted under s.302 read with s.34, sentenced to transportation for life.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal to the High Court of Rajasthan, the order of acquittal of Bhagwandas and Netram was reversed and they were convicted under s.302 read with s. 34 and sentenced to transportation for life.

facts.text: High Court affirmed acquittal of Mt. Rameshwari.

anchor.surface_text: The order as to Mt. Rameshwari was affirmed and she was acquitted. The convicted persons have obtained Special Leave to appeal under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Canal restarted flowing on May 5, 1953 after temporary closure.

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution the canal after a temporary closure restarted flowing on May 5, 1953. And although it was not his turn of water the deceased Shivlal was allowed to take the water to irrigate his fields.

facts.text: On May 6, 1953, canal flowing full capacity, Shivlal's turn 6 hours from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: On May 6 the canal was flowing to its full capacity and Shivlal was to take his turn of water which was of 6 hours duration from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m. but he watered his lands from 8 a.m. to 10-30 a.m.

facts.text: Shivlal watered lands from 8 a.m. to 10:30 a.m. because village diggi pond empty had to be filled.

anchor.surface_text: but he watered his lands from 8 a.m. to 10-30 a.m. because the village diggi pond which was empty had to be filled up.

facts.text: Mirab Ram Karan PW1 with consent of Shivlal diverted water to fill diggi, promising rest of turn after.

anchor.surface_text: Mirab Ram Karan P. W. 1 with the consent of Shivlal diverted the water for the purpose of filling up the diggi, promising him Shivlal to. get him the rest of his turn of water, i.e., for 3-1/2 hours after the diggi had been filled up.

facts.text: Diggi filled up by 1 p.m. on May 7, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The diggi was filled up by 1 p.m. on the 7th.

facts.text: Bhagwandas prevented Shivlal from diverting water to his field, claiming the turn to be his.

anchor.surface_text: Shivlal then wanted to divert the water into his field but Bhagwandas prevented him from doing so claiming the turn to be his.

facts.text: According to Ram Karan Mirab PW1, Bhagwandas turn after Surta, whose turn next after Shivlal.

anchor.surface_text: According to Ram Karan Mirab P. W. I the turn of Bhagwandas was after Surta whose turn was next to that of Shivlal.

facts.text: Bhagwandas hit Shivlal on head with kassi after shouting enemy was going.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwandas thereupon shouted that the enemy was going and hit Shivlal on the head with a kassi. Netram then hit Shivlal with lathi as a result of which he fell down

facts.text: Netram hit Shivlal with lathi, both beat him, Mt. Rameshwari joined with wooden handle of kassi.

anchor.surface_text: Netram then hit Shivlal with lathi as a result of which he fell down and then both beat Shivlal, and Mt. Rameshwari also, it was alleged, joined in this beating with a wooden handle of a kassi.

facts.text: Occurrence witnessed by Hazari PW3 grazing camels in field of Surta.

anchor.surface_text: This occurrence was witnessed by Hazari P. W. 3 who was grazing his camels in the field of Surta.

facts.text: Hazari shouted to assailants, they went away leaving kassi.

anchor.surface_text: He went up to the place where the beating was going on and shouted to the assailants who went away leaving their kassi behind.

facts.text: Shivlal seriously injured unconscious, Hazari sprinkled water, revived, asked to take to Thana.

anchor.surface_text: Hazari found Shivlal seriously injured and unconscious. He sprinkled some water on his face which revived Shivlal and the latter asked Hazari to take him to the Thana

facts.text: Hazari helped Shivlal walk to Khala threshing floor of Hukma.

anchor.surface_text: but Hazari helped him to walk up to the Khala threshing floor of Hukma which was at a short distance from that place.

facts.text: Shivlal left with Jora, Jagmal, Bhogar, Begaram, Binja by Hazari.

anchor.surface_text: Hazari P. W. 3 has stated that he left Shivlal with Jora, Jagmal, Bhogar, Begaram and Binja, and on their asking him he Hazari told them what he had seen.

facts.text: Shivlal taken to Raisinghnagar by Bhaggu and Jagmal on she-camel to shop of Gyani Ram PW4.

anchor.surface_text: Shivlal was then taken to Raisinghnagar by Bhaggu and Jagmal on a she-camel to the shop of Gyani ham P. W. 4.

facts.text: Shivlal told Gyani Ram that Bhagwandas, Netram and Rameshwari assaulted him over water dispute.

anchor.surface_text: There Shivlal told Gyani Ram also that Bhagwandas, Netram and Rameshwari had assaulted him because of the water dispute and also asked Gyani Ram to send for his son Ram Pratap

facts.text: Ram Pratap came at about 6 p.m., Shivlal repeated story to him.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Pratap came at about 6 p. m. Shivlal repeated the story to him and was then taken to the hospital by Jagmal, Bhaggu and others.

facts.text: Shivlal taken to hospital, treated by doctor PW11, died following day May 8 at 8:15 a.m.

anchor.surface_text: At the hospital he was treated by the doctor P. W. I I but died the following day 8th at 8-15 a. m.

facts.text: First Information Report based on written report Ex. P-1 by Ram Pratap s/o Shivlal, recorded May 7 at 7:30 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: The First Information Report was based on a written report Ex. P-1 by Ram Pratap s o Shivlal. It was recorded on May 7 at about 7-30 p. m.

facts.text: Shivlal had 15 injuries, injury No.1 sharp-edged, No.2 blunt, both grievous and fatal.

anchor.surface_text: According to the doctors evidence Shivlal was unconscious when he was brought to the hospital at 5 p. m, He had 15 injuries on his body, out of which injury No. 1 was with a sharp-edged weapon and injury No. 2 with a blunt weapon and both these injuries were grievous

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted accused, disbelieved prosecution evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge disbelieved the whole evidence and acquitted the accused. He was of the opinion that the evidence produced by the prosecution was not free from suspicion

facts.text: High Court accepted testimony of Hazari PW3 and dying declarations to Gyaniram PW4 and Jora PW7.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has relied upon the testimony of one eye witness Hazari P. W. 3 and two witnesses before whom Shivlal is alleged to have made two dying declarations.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside conviction of Bhagwandas and Netram.

anchor.surface_text: Although this Court will not interfere with the findings of the High Court because its conclusions on the evidence as to the guilt or innocence of the accused differ from that of the High Court, yet where the evidence is such that no Tribunal could legitimately infer

holdings.text: Hazari's testimony is unreliable because the indication of tutoring and contradictions detract materially from his reliability, making it dangerous to accept.

anchor.surface_text: There are apparent contradictions between the testimony of Hazari and Bega. The learned High Court Judges disposed of this by saying that Begas presence on the spot is open to grave doubts. As such it is, in our opinion, not proper to contradict the statement of a man who was present on the spot by using the statement of another man who was in all probability not there. The learned Judges have made the following significant observation in regard to Hazari It seems to us that Hazari had said this because the prosecution was producing Bega, and he must have been asked to say that Bega was also present. So far as the story of Hazari about -the incident itself is concerned, nothing has been brought out in his cross-examination to throw doubts on this part of his statement. They also pointed out, but attached noimportance, to other contradictions in the statements of Hazari made before the trial court and before the Police. If as observed by the learned Judges of the High Court, Hazari had mentioned the presence of Bega merely because the latter was to be produced as a prosecution witness and because he Hazari had been asked to mention it, then it would detract so materially from his reliability that it would be dangerous to accept his testimony as being of any great value which is still more diminished by the finding as to the innocence of Mt. Rameshwari.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court noted possible tutoring in Hazari's statement about Bega's presence; this undermines core reliability despite acceptance of incident part; further diminished by acquittal of Mt. Rameshwari.

holdings.text: A dying declaration of the kind relied upon is by itself insufficient for sustaining a conviction on a charge of murder, especially with infirmities and contradictions.

anchor.surface_text: their evidence cannot be a sure foundation for maintaining the conviction if the statement of Hazari the sole eye witness is disregarded, as it must be disregarded in this case because ordinarily a dying declaration of the kind which the prosecution has relied upon is by itself insufficient for sustaining a conviction on a charge of murder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dying declarations to Gyaniram and Jora suffer material contradictions at various stages; Sessions Judge rejected them; ordinarily insufficient alone for murder, cannot support conviction without reliable eyewitness.

holdings.text: It is not a satisfactory way to dispose of expert evidence by relying on medical jurisprudence books unless contradictory passages are put to the witness.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judges of the High Court disposed of this matter by saying that the doctor was comparatively young and that his statement was not in accord with the opinion expressed in books on Medical Jurisprudence by authors like Modi and Lyon. But it cannot be said that the opinions of these authors were given in regard to circumstances exactly similar to those which arose in the case now before us nor is this a satisfactory way of disposing of the evidence of an expert unless, the passages which are sought to discredit his opinion are put to him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court discredited young doctor by reference to Modi and Lyon without showing passages similar circumstances or putting to witness; Supreme Court in Sundarlal v. State of MP disapproved such practice.

holdings.text: The recovery of the kassi is a wholly neutral circumstance because it has not been proved to belong to Bhagwandas.

anchor.surface_text: The recovery of the kassi is a wholly neutral circumstance because it has not been proved that it belonged to Bhagwandas.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No proof linking kassi to accused Bhagwandas, hence provides no inculpatory evidence.

holdings.text: Where evidence is such that no tribunal could legitimately infer guilt, Supreme Court will set aside conviction under Art. 136 even differing from High Court findings.

anchor.surface_text: Although this Court will not interfere with the findings of the High Court because its conclusions on the evidence as to the guilt or innocence of the accused differ from that of the High Court, yet where the evidence is such that no Tribunal could legitimately infer from it that the accused is guilty this Court would set aside the conviction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Privy Council in Stephen Seneviratne v. King: no grounds for legitimate inference of guilt; evidence here lacks quality for such inference.

holdings.text: The evidence in this case is of such quality that no legitimate inference of guilt could properly be drawn.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Eyewitness unreliable; dying declarations infirm; medical evidence mishandled; kassi neutral; cumulative insufficiency.

holdings.text: High Court should not set aside acquittal unless substantial and compelling reasons exist; here none disclosed.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Citing Surajpal Singh, Ajmer Singh, Aher Raja Khima: High Court judgment lacks such reasons for reversing Sessions Judge acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: There are apparent contradictions between the testimony of Hazari and Bega. The learned High Court Judges disposed of this by saying that Begas presence on the spot is open to grave doubts. As such it is, in our opinion, not proper to contradict the statement of a man who was present on the spot by using the statement of another man who was in all probability not there. The learned Judges have made the following significant observation in regard to Hazari It seems to us that Hazari had said this because the prosecution was producing Bega, and he must have been asked to say that Bega was also present. So far as the story of Hazari about -the incident itself is concerned, nothing has been brought out in his cross-examination to throw doubts on this part of his statement. They also pointed out, but attached noimportance, to other contradictions in the statements of Hazari made before the trial court and before the Police. If as observed by the learned Judges of the High Court, Hazari had mentioned the presence of Bega merely because the latter was to be produced as a prosecution witness and because he Hazari had been asked to mention it, then it would detract so materially from his reliability that it would be dangerous to accept his testimony as being of any great value which is still more diminished by the finding as to the innocence of Mt. Rameshwari.

edges.explanation: The holding states it is not satisfactory to dispose of expert evidence by relying on medical books unless passages are put to the witness, directly addressing whether the High Court erred in doing so without putting the passages.

anchor.surface_text: But the learned Judges of the High Court disposed of this matter by saying that the doctor was comparatively young and that his statement was not in accord with the opinion expressed in books on Medical Jurisprudence by authors like Modi and Lyon. But it cannot be said that the opinions of these authors were given in regard to circumstances exactly similar to those which arose in the case now before us nor is this a satisfactory way of disposing of the evidence of an expert unless, the passages which are sought to discredit his opinion are put to him.
